sentence: First, the Fed was not alone in underestimating the strength of inflation that revealed itself in late 2021.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Let me start by reminding everyone of two immutable facts about setting monetary policy in the United States.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: First, we have a dual mandate from the Congress: maximum employment and price stability.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: We said that we would "aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time" to ensure that it averages 2 percent over time and that inflation expectations stay anchored.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: My projection had inflation above 2 percent for 2021 and 2022, with unemployment close to my long-run estimate by the second half of 2022.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In April 2021, I said the economy was "ready to rip," and it did.1 I chose to look at the unemployment rate and job creation as the labor market indicators I would use to assess whether we had made "substantial further progress."
label: LABEL_2

sentence: My projection was also based on the belief that the jump in inflation that occurred in March 2021 would be more persistent than many expected.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: With regard to future inflation, 13 participants projected inflation in 2022 would be at or below our 2 percent target.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In the March 2021 SEP, no Committee member expected inflation to be over 3 percent for 2021.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: As I argued in a speech last December, this view was consistent with private-sector economic forecasts.2 When inflation broke loose in March 2021, even though I had expected it to run above 2 percent in 2021 and 2022, I never thought it would reach the very high levels we have seen in recent months.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: All the suspected drivers of this surge in inflation appeared to be temporary: the one-time stimulus from fiscal policy, supply chain shocks that previous experience indicated would ease soon, and a surge in demand for goods.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: In addition, we had very accommodative monetary policy that I believed would end in 2022.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: Over the summer of 2021, the labor market and other data related to economic activity came in as I expected, and so I argued publicly that we were rapidly approaching "substantial further progress" on the employment leg of our mandate.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Also, unlike the March SEP, every Committee participant now expected inflation to be over 3 percent in 2021 and just five believed inflation would be at 2 percent or below in 2022.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In addition, the vast majority of participants now saw risks associated with inflation weighted to the upside.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: Numerous participants said that new data indicated that tapering should begin sooner than anticipated.3 Thus, in June, after observing high inflation for only three months, the Committee was moving in a hawkish direction and was considering tapering sooner and pulling liftoff forward.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: At the July FOMC meeting, the minutes show that most participants believed that "substantial further progress" had been made on inflation but not employment.4 Tapering was not viewed as imminent by most participants.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: I considered this a punch in the gut and relevant to a decision on when to start tapering.6 Nevertheless, the September FOMC statement noted that the economy had made progress toward the Committee's goals and that, if progress continued, it would soon be time to taper.7 Up until October, monthly core personal consumption expenditures (PCE) inflation was actually slowing.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: So, up until the first week of October 2021, the story of high inflation being temporary was holding up, and the labor market improvements had slowed but were continuing.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: Based on the incoming data, the FOMC announced the start of tapering at its early November meeting.8 It was the October and November consumer price index (CPI) reports that showed that the deceleration of inflation from April to September was short lived and year-over-year inflation had topped 6 percent.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: It became clear that the high inflation realizations were not as temporary as originally thought.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: It was at this pointâ€”with a clearer picture of inflation and revised labor market data in handâ€”that the FOMC pivoted.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: These forecasts and forward guidance had a significant effect on raising market interest rates, even though we did nothing with our primary policy tool, the federal funds rate, in December 2021.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In terms of missing on inflation, policymakers' projections looked very much like most of the public's.
label: LABEL_1

sentence: For example, as shown in table 1, the median SEP forecast for 2021 Q4/Q4 PCE inflation was very similar to the consensus from the Blue Chip, which is a compilation of private sector forecasts.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: In short, nearly everyone was behind the curve when it came to forecasting the magnitude and persistence of inflation.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Second, as I mentioned, you cannot answer this question without taking a stand on the employment leg of our mandate.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Many of our critics tend to focus only on the inflation aspect of our mandate and ignore the employment leg of our mandate.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: Two consecutive weak job reports didn't square with a rapidly falling unemployment rate.
label: LABEL_0

sentence: As shown in table 2, revisions to changes in payroll employment since late last summer have been quite substantial.
label: LABEL_2

sentence: From the original reports to the current estimate, the change in payroll employment has been revised up nearly 1.5 million.

sentence: But no one knew, and that's the nature of making monetary policy in real time.
